customer_addr:
3930 West Land Park Drive
Sacramento, CA 95822

citations.narrative:
In several kitchen areas that serve birds, including the main kitchen, cleaning supplies such as bleach that are harmful to
the birds were on lower shelves. Substances such as cleaning supplies and disinfectants that are harmful to birds but that
are required for normal husbandry practices must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas but may be stored
in cabinets... in properly labeled containers that are adequately secured to prevent potential harm to the birds.
Correct by 14 January, 2024

In the thick billed parrot and hawk-headed (Red-Fan) parrot enclosures, there were exposed screws where it appeared
the birds had chewed on areas of the nest boxes, and the screws were left exposed. Primary enclosures must be
constructed and maintained so that there are no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds.
Corrected at the time of inspection.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the facility has individual species plans and provided appropriate enrichment within the avian enclosures, the
facility did not have a documented environmental enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow an appropriate plan for
environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of each group of birds with similar
requirements. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping,
environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint and exemptions to the plan, in accordance with currently
accepted professional standards.
Correct by 16 January, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the manager.
Additional Inspectors:
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.150(e) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In several kitchen areas that serve birds, including the main kitchen, cleaning supplies such as bleach that are harmful to 
the birds were on lower shelves. Substances such as cleaning supplies and disinfectants that are harmful to birds but that 
are required for normal husbandry practices must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas but may be stored 
in cabinets... in properly labeled containers that are adequately secured to prevent potential harm to the birds. 
 
Correct by 14 January, 2024 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In the thick billed parrot and hawk-headed (Red-Fan) parrot enclosures, there were exposed screws where it appeared 
the birds had chewed on areas of the nest boxes, and the screws were left exposed. Primary enclosures must be 
constructed and maintained so that there are no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. 
 
Corrected at the time of inspection. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Although the facility has individual species plans and provided appropriate enrichment within the avian enclosures, the 
facility did not have a documented environmental enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian 
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow an appropriate plan for 
environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of each group of birds with similar 
requirements. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, 
environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint and exemptions to the plan, in accordance with currently 
accepted professional standards. 
 
Correct by 16 January, 2024

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the manager. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
